Legal_Issue: Does the quashing of a summons to a witness in an R.C.M.P. disciplinary hearing violate procedural fairness or Charter rights under sections 7 and 11(d)?
Application_Facts: Cannon sought to summon a prosecuting officer as a witness, alleging conspiracy. The board quashed the summons, finding insufficient evidence.
Decision_Outcome: The Federal Court dismissed Cannon's application.
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the board's decision to quash the summons
Court_Ruling: No violation of procedural fairness or Charter rights occurred. The board acted within its jurisdiction.
Claimant_Status: Cannon, the accused in the disciplinary proceedings
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness and Charter rights under sections 7 and 11(d)
Legal_Standard: Section 7 protects fundamental justice; section 11(d) applies to criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings requiring independent tribunals.
Assessment_Factor: Nature of the proceeding (disciplinary vs. penal)
Sufficiency of evidence for witness relevance
Applicable_Legislation: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Procedural_Issue: Quashing of a witness summons at an interlocutory stage
Application_Basis: Board found insufficient evidence to justify the summons
Evidence_Assessed: Insufficient evidence to support need for witness testimony
Relief_Sought: Quashing of the board’s decision to disallow the witness summons
Governing_Rule: Boards have discretion over procedural matters unless constrained by statute or procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence linking the witness to relevant issues
Outcome: Application dismissed; no solicitor-client costs awarded
Cause_Description: Cannon was accused of breaching the R.C.M.P. Code of Conduct, leading to disciplinary proceedings where he attempted to summon a prosecuting officer as a witness.
Evidence_Handling: Summons quashed due to lack of demonstrated relevance
Evidence_Issues: Relevance and necessity of proposed witness
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the board exceeded its authority in quashing the summons
Evidence_Assessment: The board assessed that the summoned witness lacked material relevance
Decision_Rationale: The decision was interlocutory and within the board's procedural authority; section 11(d) inapplicable as proceeding was not penal
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to establish evidentiary basis for witness summons

Legal_Issue: Does the quashing of a summons to a witness in an interlocutory decision violate procedural fairness or Charter rights under sections 7 and 11(d)?
Governing_Law: Canadian law on judicial review and administrative procedure
Application_Facts: Cannon sought to summon Sgt. Keating as a witness but the board quashed the summons.
Decision_Outcome: The Federal Court dismissed Cannon's application for judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the board’s decision to quash the witness summons
Court_Ruling: No violation of procedural fairness or Charter rights; no special circumstances warranting intervention
Claimant_Status: Cannon, the accused in the disciplinary proceedings
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness and Charter rights under sections 7 and 11(d)
Legal_Standard: Section 7 ensures fundamental justice; section 11(d) applies to criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings
Applicable_Legislation: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Procedural_Issue: Quashing of a witness summons during interlocutory phase
Evidence_Used: Attempt to call Sgt. Keating as a witness
Application_Basis: Board determined the witness was not necessary for fair adjudication
Evidence_Assessed: Relevance and materiality of Sgt. Keating's testimony
Relief_Sought: Overturning the board’s decision to quash the summons
Governing_Rule: Judicial review typically limited to final decisions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate necessity or materiality of witness
Cause_Description: Cannon was accused of sexual harassment, leading to disciplinary proceedings where he attempted to summon a prosecuting officer as a witness.
Evidence_Handling: Board exercised discretion to exclude witness based on lack of demonstrated relevance
Evidence_Issues: Materiality and admissibility of proposed witness testimony
Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of court’s power to intervene in interlocutory administrative decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Board found no compelling reason to require the witness
Decision_Rationale: Proceeding was internal disciplinary in nature, not penal; no special circumstances justifying review
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to meet threshold for compulsion of witness at interlocutory stage
